utterances: Very, very.
Ah, I was out of my mind.
I was excited.
But then the second round was, of course, against the hated Yankees, and they really went down without much of a fight.
They lost that series in five games.
And I was totally stunned.
I went out and I talked to my daughters and we decided we were going to get a puppy.
But as a result of it Betsy became a huge Red Sox fan.
And that was not really fair because in those eight years the Sox have subsequently won two world championships.
And people have been born, lived full lives and died before that and never seen one world championship.
(Soundbite of music)
Well, listeners Charlie Isenman and Betsy Hudson still roots for the Red Sox from their home in Shrewsbury, Massachusetts.
They've been married 13 years enjoying, they say, their two wonderful daughters.
Here's your next Homework assignment for Veterans' Day next weekend.
Send us a story of a war memento in your family, maybe one related to a loss, maybe one related to a homecoming.
And you can send your e-mail to homework@npr.org.
And make sure you include a phone number or you can call in your story to the Homework hotline, listen up, 202-408-5183.
At the White House, it was the last day behind the lectern for Spokesman Tony Snow.
In an unusual display of warmth, reporters applauded Snow as he stepped into the briefing room.
(Soundbite of applause)
And the man who usually spars with journalists at those daily briefings returned the gesture with praise for the reporters.
This job has been the most fun I have ever had, the most satisfying, fulfilling job.
I'm sorry I have to leave it.
But I have got to say it has been a real honor and a pleasure working with everybody in this room.
Tony Snow will stay on the job through Friday, but he's handed over the daily press briefing to his successor, Dana Perino.
Snow is resigning, as he says, to make some much-needed money on the lecture circuit, and possibly write a memoir.
He's also battling a recurrence of colon cancer.
Snow spoke with us this afternoon, and since he's still technically the press secretary, I asked him if the president's speech tomorrow night is meant to brace the U.S.
for a long-term presence in Iraq despite the plan to withdraw up to 30,000 by next summer.
I hate to, sort of, play cat and mouse with you, but it's what I've been doing with the rest of the press.
I'm going to let the president announce his policies.
However, I do want to knockdown one thing.
I don't think anybody have suggested that there is going to be a long-term U.S.
presence that's identical to what we have today.
Nobody is talking about 160,000 frontline combat troops for the next 10 years.
But having said that, I think he sees diminishing numbers as you get increased capability among Iraqi fighting forces.
But, again, that's what General Petraeus was laying out for Congress.
We're going to have to let the president announce what his policies are going to be, and he will do that tomorrow night.

Now, anyone who watches the presidential briefings knows that the job of the White House spokesman is - or spokeswoman is always very difficult, but you had a particular tough run, defending an increasingly unpopular president and an unpopular war.
Has the president and have you, to some degree, lost an important commodity - the public's trust.
The idea that you're telling trueâ€¦
No, I don't think - no, I don't think so.
I mean, I hate to day it but the public trust in journalists is far lower than it is in presidents.
I think you looked at it this way.
This actually isn't a hard job; it's a wonderful job.
And I came here because I believed in what the president is doing.
And knowing that a war is unpopular in a time like this, I think there is a general suspicion about the nature of politics.
It's certainly been visited on, Democrats and Republicans alike, in unhistoric low ratings of congressional approval.
And, you know, I think what you do in a time like this is you continue to do your best to address the problems honestly and as best you can.
And if there's unpopularity, then, yeah, well, so be it.
You ask yourself, what is the mission, what are the challenges.
It's a very exciting time to be in this White House.
And frankly, I'm sorry I have to go.
But before you go, take us into that pressroom.
We always see you walking out from the lower press office, walking up to the lectern.
What's going through your mind when you do that?
You know, I love it.
I love the briefings.
It is so much fun.
So I go into a room of very good reporters and I have the responsibility for talking about the president's policies and what's going on, and doing as much as I can to answer questions.
But, for instance, a lot of people want to know about tomorrow night's speech, I'm not going to tell them anything about tomorrow night's speech.
It is of necessity, kind of a cat and mouse game that we're going to play for the day and a half.
They understand that.
UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #3: Go.
Control.
And Austin in a lot of ways is still a small town.
So it's like - when South by Southwest is in town, it's like a medieval fair, you know?
The gene pool deepens a little bit.
You know, South by Southwest is a great time to quit your job and fall in love, I think.
At least for a week...
For a week.
At least for one week.
It's also a little bit like invading Vikings.
(Laughter) That's right.
In leather pants.
In leather pants and purple hair.
All right, Doug.
Doug is like this.
He's just shaking his head no.
It's good for the city.
But I take ride-hailing and ride-sharing, you know?
And, you know, forget it.
Do you think that - I'm also just wondering what it's like to be - and maybe this is a myth - like a sea - like a little island of blue in a sea of red.
Do you at least feel some sort of comforting...
It's the - it's the - it's the blueberry in the bowl of tomato soup.
Oh, is that right?
It's the diamond in the goat's butt.
(LAUGHTER)
Genevieve, that's...
We'll go with my metaphor.
(Laughter) Fair enough.
So, you know, the little island of blue in the sea of red.
Do you at least feel, like, some compadres, like, this week?
You figure people will maybe share your politics a little bit?
Yeah.
Yeah.
Sure.
Well, and I think this South by Southwest has definitely a political bent.
Yeah.
You know, Biden was here.
And one of the things I've noticed this year is that it's a lot more - a lot more diverse than it has been in the past.
And thank goodness, because South by Southwest at first wasn't.
And it was definitely a criticism.
And I think they've taken it on board at some level.
South by is a pain in a lot of ways.
But on the other hand, it's, like, the place to be this week.
And that - you know, for me, I kind of enjoy the idea that all my relatives out scattered around the country are thinking, wow, Doug lives in a really cool place apparently.
People are having movies in their backyards, bands in their backyards, parties - block parties in the street.
You've got people wandering around, trying to find the room they've rented in somebody's house and don't know where they are.
(Laughter) Yeah.
Yeah.
So it's really kind of a - I mean, it's...
But you don't want it going on next door to you.
So, Jeff, tell me what you want people to know.
